page.title: 07The Chapel.Steeple Bumpstead
page.content: {Nonconformity}was strong in the Parish of Steeple Bumpstead from the beginning of the 16th century, and it is interesting to note that the Vicar of Steeple Bumpstead - Reverend Edward Symmes was one of the 2,000{dissenting {clergy}who left the State Church of England in 1662, although he did not found a Free Church here. In{1760}a {nonconformist place of worship}was established in a barn which stood on the site of the present Congregational church. In{1789}the barn was bought for Â£40 by Edward Fitch, acting on behalf of the Congregation. In{1800 the barn was pulled down and a{small {chapel}built. In{1848}the congregation built the{British School}which was the first public school for miles around. {The present chapel}with its 70ft. spire was erected in{1883.}Services are held every Sunday morning.
